document: Legacy Information Systems (LIS) are vital, large-scale systems that resist modification. This chapter covers LIS definitions, characteristics (such as being geriatric and poorly documented), and solutions like wrapping and migration. Wrapping techniques include forward/backward database wrappers, system service, application, and function wrappers, across five levels of encapsulation: process, transaction, progress, module, and procedure. [cite: 38, 39, 41, 42, 60, 86, 146]

questions.question: The Oxford English Dictionary defines legacy as anything handed down by an ancestor or predecessor. [cite: 34, 37]
Brodie and Stonebraker define legacy systems as systems that easily adapt to changing business requirements. [cite: 38, 39]
Bennett defines legacy software systems as large systems that are vital to an organization even if we don't know how to cope with them. [cite: 40, 41]
A typical feature of a legacy system is that it contains millions of lines of code. [cite: 42, 43]
Legacy systems are usually written in modern, cutting-edge programming languages. [cite: 42, 45]
Legacy systems are characterized by a lack of consistent documentation. [cite: 42, 46]
The data management in legacy systems is often based on flat-file structures. [cite: 42, 47]
Legacy systems are considered easy to expand or modify. [cite: 42, 49]
There are exactly six identified categories of solutions for legacy information systems. [cite: 59, 60]
One solution for a legacy system is to 'Freeze' it. [cite: 60, 62]
Wrapping a legacy system means rewriting its entire codebase from scratch. [cite: 78]
A wrapper provides a new interface while hiding the complexity of the old component. [cite: 78]
Encapsulation layers can communicate with legacy components through sockets or RPCs. [cite: 79]
The forward wrapper (f-wrapper) approach involves migrating data first before developing new components. [cite: 94, 96]
In the backward wrapper (b-wrapper) approach, legacy components access new data via wrappers. [cite: 96, 97]
System service wrappers support customized access to routing, sorting, and printing. [cite: 128, 130]
Function wrappers provide access to the full program rather than just specific parts. [cite: 135, 137, 138]
There are five levels of granularity in encapsulation, with procedures at the lowest level. [cite: 146, 153]
At the process level of encapsulation, a wrapper takes over output files to be forwarded to the client. [cite: 161, 163]
At the transaction level, the wrapper is a program that simulates a user terminal. [cite: 164, 166]
